metadata.title: Everything You Need To Know About Jupyter Notebooks | by Bharath K | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Everything You Need To Know About Jupyter Notebooks
metadata.description: The Jupyter Notebook is an open-source web application that allows you to create and share documents that contain live code, equations, visualizations, and narrative text. Its uses include data…

all_paragraphs: The Jupyter Notebook is an open-source web application that allows you to create and share documents that contain live code, equations, visualizations, and narrative text. Its uses include data cleaning and transformation, numerical simulation, statistical modeling, data visualization, machine learning, and much more.

Jupyter Notebook (formerly IPython Notebooks) is a web-based interactive computational environment for creating Jupyter notebook documents. The “notebook” term can colloquially make reference to many different entities, mainly the Jupyter web application, Jupyter Python web server, or Jupyter document format depending on context.
According to the official website of Jupyter, Project Jupyter exists to develop open-source software, open-standards, and services for interactive computing across dozens of programming languages.

Jupyter Book is an open-source project for building books and documents from computational material. It allows the user to construct the content in a mixture of Markdown, an extended version of Markdown called MyST, Maths & Equations using MathJax, Jupyter Notebooks, reStructuredText, the output of running Jupyter Notebooks at build time. Multiple output formats can be produced (currently single files, multipage HTML web pages and PDF files).

Now that we have a brief understanding of the concept of Project Jupyter and the Jupyter Notebooks, and we have established that these Notebooks are quite revolutionary in the modern ages, let us proceed to understand the more in-depth details of this amazing interactive environment in the next sections.

The best method of installing the Jupyter Notebooks is by the installation of the Anaconda package. The Jupyter Notebook and the Jupyter Lab comes pre-installed in the Anaconda package, and you don’t have to install this on your own.

One of the requirements here is Python, either Python 3.3 or greater or Python 2.7. The general recommendation is that you use the Anaconda distribution to install both Python and the notebook application. The advantage of Anaconda is that you have access to over 720 packages that can easily be installed with Anaconda’s conda, a package, dependency, and environment manager.
I would highly recommend checking out the following two links for the installation of Anaconda on your system. You can access them from here and here.

However, if you are not interested in installing the Anaconda package manager, and you want to simply install the Jupyter Notebook the Pythonic way, make sure you have downloaded the latest Python Version (which is 3.9 at the time of writing of this article), and then proceed to issue the following command in the command prompt or PowerShell.

With the installation of the Jupyter Notebook complete, you should be able to access it successfully. Just type the jupyter notebook command in the command prompt or PowerShell. This should launch your Jupyter Notebook in your selected web browser with a local hosting URL, which is labeled as http://localhost:8888.

To follow with this section of the tutorial, I would highly recommend all of you have your Jupyter Notebooks open side by side. This will help you to follow along, analyze, and grasp most of the essentials of the Jupyter Notebook more easily.
After launching the Jupyter Notebook on your local host web browser, you should be directed to a page that looks as follows —
Note: All images are zoomed in to 175% for better clarity.

I have launched my Jupyter Notebook in an empty folder, and hence you can notice that the content list of my launched host is currently empty. We can change this by simply clicking on the New button and selecting the Python 3 option from the menu that is provided upon your click.
After clicking on the Python 3 option from the New dropdown menu, you will be directed to a new Notebook that is created. It will look similar to the screenshot below.

The first thing we will do before looking into the various menu options available in the Jupyter Notebook is changing our title to the desired name of our choice. I will be labeling it as Test, and it should look something similar to the image shown below.
Upon cross checking the local host URL that was launched, you will now notice that there is a new Jupyter Notebook file that is created in the specific directory.

You can add any number of Python or other files in the directory as you desire, and it will be constantly updated. With this basic introduction to the Jupyter Notebook platform, let us proceed to understand most of the significant menu options available.

Note: In this section, I will be focusing mostly on only the more important menu options that are usually used on a consistent basis. I will skip other additional commands that are not frequently used.

The kernel is a computer program at the core of a computer’s operating system that has complete control over everything in the system. It is the “portion of the operating system code that is always resident in memory”, and facilitates interactions between hardware and software components.

A notebook kernel is a “computational engine” that executes the code contained in a Notebook document. The ipython kernel, referenced in this guide, executes python code. Kernels for many other languages exist (official kernels).

When you open a Notebook document, the associated kernel is automatically launched. When the notebook is executed (either cell-by-cell or with menu Cell -> Run All), the kernel performs the computation and produces the results. Depending on the type of computations, the kernel may consume significant CPU and RAM. Note that the RAM is not released until the kernel is shut-down.
Let us proceed to analyze the various functions in the Kernel menu icon that will be useful for Data Science projects.
Since we have already discussed the “File” and “Kernel options in the main menu bar in detail, let us briefly look at the other options and the functionalities they offer us.
We will discuss this icon palette starting from the first icon, which is the save option, until the end. This command palette will be useful for quickly completing the majority of your tasks.

You can run the notebook document step-by-step (one cell a time) by pressing crtl + enter for running the particular cell or shift + enter to run the current cell as well create a new cell below it. You can run the whole notebook in a single step by clicking on the menu Cell -> Run All.

The above image is a representation of how each of these cells can run as separate code blocks. In the first code cell you can notice that we have used the print statement for printing a basic “Hello World!” program.

However, similar to a command prompt or python shell, the variables defined, assigned, or obtained can be run at the end of the code cell or in a new code cell to receive the held value. The code cells [2] and [3] are a representation of the same.

Finally, the code cells can also be used as a calculator to perform a variety of tasks ranging from addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, power (**), and many more functions. You can also utilize these code blocks for programming your python or Data Science projects.

Text can be added to Jupyter Notebooks using Markdown cells. You can change the cell type to Markdown by using the Cell menu, the toolbar, or the key shortcut m. Markdown is a popular markup language that is a superset of HTML.

Markdowns are a way to make your Jupyter Notebooks more presentable and help to make the viewers or readers a more concise understanding of your code. You can add headers, images, widgets, bullet points, ordered lists, hyperlinks, and so much more.
More details about its specifications can be found here. To learn more about Markdowns visit the official documentation here.
Below is a image representation of most of the essential shortcut commands of the Jupyter Notebook.

I have discussed most of the necessary shortcuts throughout the course of this article. However, if you want to learn and explore more about the various shortcut options available, then click on the help and open shortcut command options for a more detailed guide to these shortcut choices in the Jupyter Notebook.

We have understood some of the details and in-depth mechanisms of Jupyter Notebooks. We can conclude that these Notebooks are absolutely amazing in performing tasks related to visualizations, cleansing of data, and any projects related to data science or Python in general.
To quickly brief up some of the pros and cons of Jupyter Notebooks, they can be considered as provided below.

If you want a concise guide of more than ten awesome Python editors, then I would highly recommend all of you to check out the following article, whose link is provided below. It has a brief understanding of some awesome editor choices and alternative options that you can use as your IDE.

Jupyter Notebooks are more popular than ever right now and is used by almost every major company for its interactive environment and the fact that sharing these notebooks is very easy. An example of this is the project developed by Google known as the Google Colaboratory.

Colaboratory (also known as Colab) is a free Jupyter notebook environment that runs in the cloud and stores its notebooks on Google Drive. Colab was originally an internal Google project; an attempt was made to open source all the code and work more directly upstream, leading to the development of the “Open in Colab” Google Chrome extension, but this eventually ended, and Colab development continued internally.

As of October 2019, the Colaboratory UI only allows you to create notebooks with Python 2 and Python 3 kernels; however, if you have an existing notebook whose kernelspec is IR or Swift, that will work, since both R and Swift are installed in the container. Julia language can also work on Colab (with e.g. Python and GPUs; Google’s tensor processing units also work with Julia on Colab.

Overall, Jupyter Notebooks are a fantastic piece of work for every Data Science enthusiast and something every lover of this field must explore. Whether you love it or hate it, it is undeniable that this workspace is an innovation for the upcoming years due to its high interactivity, compactness, and easily shareable capabilities.

Project Jupyter is a nonprofit organization created to “develop open-source software, open-standards, and services for interactive computing across dozens of programming languages”. Spun off from IPython in 2014 by Fernando Pérez, Project Jupyter supports execution environments in several dozen languages.

Project Jupyter’s name is a reference to the three core programming languages supported by Jupyter, which are Julia, Python and R, and also a homage to Galileo’s notebooks recording the discovery of the moons of Jupiter. Project Jupyter has developed and supported the interactive computing products Jupyter Notebook, JupyterHub, and JupyterLab.

A Jupyter Notebook document is a JSON document, following a versioned schema, containing an ordered list of input/output cells which can contain code, text (using Markdown), mathematics, plots and rich media, usually ending with the “.ipynb” extension.

A Jupyter Notebook can be converted to a number of open standard output formats (HTML, presentation slides, LaTeX, PDF, ReStructuredText, Markdown, Python) through “Download As” in the web interface, via the nbconvert library or “jupyter nbconvert” command line interface in a shell.

To simplify visualisation of Jupyter notebook documents on the web, the nbconvert library is provided as a service through NbViewer which can take a URL to any publicly available notebook document, convert it to HTML on the fly and display it to the user.

In this article, we understand almost all of the details pertaining to Jupyter Notebooks. We learned about the “Project Jupyter” and how the Jupyter Notebook, with its high-level interactivity and easily shareable features, is making an evolutionary change for data science enthusiasts. Despite having a few cons, the Jupyter Notebook stands out as one of the best Interactive development environments for Python and Data Science projects.

The Jupyter Notebook is an absolutely fantastic option to get started with data science and machine learning. These Notebooks can be shared with anyone and helps to collaborate code more efficiently and effectively. I would highly recommend using the Jupyter Notebook as well because you can use each code block separately and you also have the option to use markdowns. It is widely used in lots of profitable companies.

I hope this concise guide was able to help out the viewers to understand the concept of Jupyter Notebooks and how to make better use of this IDE. Feel free to let me know if I missed out on something that you think I should have covered in this article.

There are so many other IDE options to choose from, lots of them, to be honest! But don’t be overwhelmed. I would like to reiterate that there is no right or wrong choice of the IDE. In the end, choose the editor that you feel you are the most comfortable with and enjoy using the most.
Check out some of my other articles that you might enjoy reading!
Thank you all for sticking on till the end. I hope all of you enjoyed reading the article. Wish you all a wonderful day!
Love to explore and learn new concepts. Extremely interested in AI, deep learning, robots, and the universe. LinkedIn — www.linkedin.com/in/bharath-k-421090194
